verses.verse: ((1 The woman seduced by the serpent,6 enticeth her husband to sin.8 They both flee from God.14 They three are punished.15 Christ is promised.19 Man is dust.22 Man is cast out of Paradise.) ) Now the serpent was more (As Satan can change himself into an Angel of light, so did he abuse the wisdom of the serpent to deceive man.) subtle than any beast of the field, which the Lord God had made: and he (God suffered Satan to make the serpent his instrument and to speak in him.) said to the woman, Yea, hath God indeed said, ye shall not eat of every tree of the garden?
And the woman said unto the serpent, We eat of the fruit of the trees of the garden.

But of the fruit of the tree which is in the midst of the garden, God hath said, Ye shall not eat of it, neither shall ye touch it, (In doubting of God’s threatenings she yielded to Satan.) lest ye die.

Then the (Cross references: : 2 Cor. 11:3) serpent said to the woman, Ye shall not die at all, (This is Satan’s chiefest subtlety, to cause us not to fear God’s threatenings.) (Hebrew, die the death.)

But God doth know that when ye shall eat thereof, your eyes shall be opened, and ye shall be as gods, (As though he should say, God doth not forbid you to eat of the fruit, save that he knoweth that if ye should eat thereof, ye should be like to him.) knowing good and evil.

So the woman (seeing that the tree was good for meat, and that it was pleasant to the eyes, and a tree to be desired, to get knowledge) took of the fruit thereof, and did (1 Tim. 2:14) eat, and gave also to her husband with her, and he (Not so much to please his wife, as moved by ambition at her persuasion.) did eat.

Then the eyes of them both were opened, and they (They began to feel their misery, but they sought not to God for remedy.) knew that they were naked, and they sewed fig tree leaves together, and made themselves (Hebrew, things to gird about them to hide their privities.) breeches.

¶ Afterward they heard the voice of the Lord God walking in the garden in the (Or, wind.) cool of the day, and the man and his wife (The sinful conscience fleeth God’s presence.) hid themselves from the presence of the Lord God among the trees of the garden.
But the Lord God called to the man, and said unto him, Where art thou?

Who said, I heard thy voice in the garden and was afraid: because I was (His hypocrisy appeareth in that he hid the cause of his nakedness, which was the transgression of God’s commandment.) naked, therefore I hid myself.
And he said, Who told thee that thou wast naked? Hast thou eaten of the tree whereof I commanded thee that thou shouldest not eat?

Then the man said, The woman which thou (His wickedness and lack of true repentance appeareth in this that he burdeneth God with his fault, because he had given him a wife.) gavest to be with me, she gave me of the tree, and I did eat.
And the Lord God said to the woman, Why hast thou done this? And the woman said, (Instead of confessing her sin, she increaseth it by accusing the serpent.) The serpent beguiled me, and I did eat.

¶ Then the Lord God said to the serpent, (He asked the reason of Adam and his wife, because he would bring them to repentance, but he asketh not the serpent, because he would show him no mercy.) Because thou hast done this, thou art cursed above all cattle, and above every beast of the field: upon thy belly shalt thou go, and (As a vile and contemptible beast, Isa. 65:25.) dust shalt thou eat all the days of thy life.

I will also put enmity between (He chiefly meaneth Satan, by whose motion and craft the serpent deceived the woman.) thee and the woman, and between thy seed and her seed. He shall break thine (That is, the power of sin and death.) head, and thou shalt (Satan shall sting Christ and his members, but not overcome them.) bruise his heel.

¶ Unto the woman he said, I will greatly increase thy (The Lord comforteth Adam by the promise of the blessed seed, and also punisheth the body for the sin which the soul should have been punished for; that the spirit having conceived hope of forgiveness, might live by faith.) sorrows, and thy conceptions. In sorrow shalt thou bring forth children, and thy desire shall be subject to thine husband, and he shall (1 Cor. 14:34) rule over thee.

¶ Also to Adam he said, Because thou hast obeyed the voice of thy wife, and hast eaten of the tree, (whereof I commanded thee, saying, Thou shalt not eat of it) (The transgression of God’s commandment was the cause that both mankind and all other creatures were subject to the curse.) cursed is the earth for thy sake: in sorrow shalt thou eat of it all the days of thy life.
(These are not the natural fruits of the earth, but proceed of the corruption of sin.) Thorns also and thistles shall it bring forth to thee, and thou shalt eat the herb of the field.
In the sweat of thy face shalt thou eat bread till thou return to the earth: for out of it wast thou taken, because thou art dust, and to dust shalt thou return.
(And the man called his wife’s name Eve, because she was the mother of all living)
Unto Adam also and to his wife did the Lord God (Or, gave them knowledge to make themselves coats.) make coats of skins, and clothed them.

¶ And the Lord God said, (By this derision he reproacheth Adam’s misery, whereinto he was fallen by ambition.) Behold, the man is become as one of us, to know good and evil. And now lest he put forth his hand, and (Adam deprived of life, lost also the sign thereof.) take also of the tree of life, and eat, and live forever,
Therefore the Lord God sent him forth from the garden of Eden, to till the earth, whence he was taken.
Thus he cast out the man, and at the East side of the garden of Eden he set the Cherubims, and the blade of a sword shaken, to keep the way of the tree of life.
